fields.physical_description:
Softwood centre table with sliding lid over a single compartment with carved ornament on three sides, and a single drawer (with hexagonal wood handle and carved front) that slides forwards or backwards. The table stands on 4 carved legs joined by an X-shape stretcher.

The main frame consists of two carved side pieces (each one a deep rail morticed-and-tenoned to two carved legs. These side pieces are joined by an X-shape lapped stretcher at low level, and two lateral rails below the drawer, one front and one back, secured by loose tenons. The plank lid slides on two battens which are cut with a groove that fits over a lip on the compartment beneath. (In 2007 and 2010 the lid was jammed shut.) The main compartment is dovetailed, probably with a nailed, plank bottom which is in turn probably nailed to the main frame. The drawer is supported on each side by a batten nailed to the top of the side, which runs in a groove cut into each side piece. The drawer bottom consistss of lateral boards nailed up.
fields.dimensions: Height: 72.5 cm, Width: 117 cm, Depth: 101 cm
fields.bibliography: Similar objects have been sold at: Christie's South Kensington 21/06/2011: Lot 541 'a Swiss elm cherry and birch rent table'. Sotheby's London 17/11/2010: Lot 344 'a Dutch oak and walnut table de changeur part 17th century and later'.
fields.history_note: Purchased from Messrs. Rabb & Knapp (Antiquarian dealers), 5 Alter Markt, Frankfurt, Germany, for 140 marks (£6. 16. 7.), 'damaged and portions missing'. A. B. Skinner and W.W. Watts 'visited the shop of these dealers' and reported on 25 Nov. 1907 'Oak Table from Fulda or the neighbourhood. This piece of furniture belongs to a type which is practically unrepresented in the Museum. There being only one rather rough specimen from the Tyrol now at Bethnal Green. It will look very well when cleaned and rewaxed.'
